title: Data Cleaning: Exercises
text:
Recommended: Complete these exercises in the dedicated Posit Cloud work space, which comes with

all packages pre-installed, and
an Rmarkdown document to fill in.

It will be helpful to peek here to verify that your tables generated in Posit Cloud match the desired output (or even to peek at the Code Solution if your cleaned tables donâ€™t look right).
Click here to enter the R/Medicine Posit cloud work space
Otherwise: Follow along this document, work on your personal computer, and challenge yourself not to peek at the code solutions until you have completed the exercise.

title: Principles of Data Cleaning
text:
ðŸ—“ June 6, 2023 | 9:30am - 1:00pm EDT
ðŸ¨ Virtual
ðŸ’¥ FREE workshop registration

title: Principles of Data Cleaning
text:
Learning objectives

To import Excel files with (common, messy) data problems.
To address and clean common messy data problems in each variable
To address and clean data with more complex meta-problems, like pivoting to long format for data analysis, dealing with multi-column headers, color-coded data (gah!), and un-pivoting pivot tables into tidy data.

title: Principles of Data Cleaning
text:
Is this course for me?
If your answer to any of the following questions is â€œyesâ€, then this is the right workshop for you.

Do you frequently receive untidy data for analysis in Excel spreadsheets?
Does this drive you slightly batty?
Do you want to learn how to make your life easier with a suite of data cleaning tools?

The workshop is designed for those with some experience in R. It will be assumed that participants can perform basic data manipulation. Experience with the {tidyverse} and the %>%/|> operator is a plus, but not required.

title: Principles of Data Cleaning
text:
Prework
Before attending the workshop please have the following installed and configured on your machine.

Recent version of R
Recent version of RStudio
Recent version of packages used in workshop.
instll_pkgs <- c("tidyverse", "tidyxl", "unpivotr")
install.packages(instll_pkgs)
Ensure you can import data from a Microsoft Excel spreadsheet to R ??

Save a a Microsoft Excel spreadsheet in a known folder on your computer.
Open RStudio install/load (library) the packages {readxl} (link) and {openxlsx} (link)
Import the data from the spreadsheet into R using the path to the correct folder with either package.

title: Data Cleaning
text:
Variable names, cleaner
Variable names as imported:


janitor::clean_names() removes special characters and implements snake case by default:

df_raw |> janitor::clean_names()

title: Data Cleaning
text:
Recoding

ProblemSolutionConfirm



df_clean <- df_raw |>
  janitor::clean_names()

df_clean |> 
  count(ethnic)

A tibble: 6 Ã— 2
ethnic n   1 Hispanic 1 2 NOT hispanic 1 3 hispamnic 1 4 hispanic 3 5 not hispanic 24 6  1






df_clean <- df_raw |>
  janitor::clean_names() |> 
  mutate(
    ethnic_clean = case_when(
      ethnic %in%  c("hispanic", "Hispanic", "hispamnic") ~ "hispanic",
      ethnic %in%  c("NOT hispanic", "not hispanic") ~ "not hispanic",
    )
  )

df_clean |> 
  count(ethnic_clean)

A tibble: 3 Ã— 2
ethnic_clean n   1 hispanic 5 2 not hispanic 25 3  1






df_clean |> 
  count(ethnic_clean, ethnic)

A tibble: 6 Ã— 3
ethnic_clean ethnic n    1 hispanic Hispanic 1 2 hispanic hispamnic 1 3 hispanic hispanic 3 4 not hispanic NOT hispanic 1 5 not hispanic not hispanic 24 6   1
